elements.title: carbatinae (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the carbatinae (examples pictured), shoes worn in ancient Greece and Rome, were single pieces of leather tied onto the foot?

elements.title: Lamia Al-Gailani Werr (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Lamia Al-Gailani Werr helped rebuild the Iraq Museum after it was looted in the 2003 American-led invasion of Iraq?

elements.title: Wager Island (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that of approximately 140 men stranded after a shipwreck on Wager Island in 1741, only 36 returned alive to Britain, according to Rear Admiral C. H. Layman?

elements.title: Roy McGrath (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Roy McGrath, who was the chief of staff to Maryland governor Larry Hogan, was wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and was killed during a shootout by agents?

elements.title: The Reconstruction of Nations (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the 2003 book The Reconstruction of Nations describes how "national reconciliation is possible after even the most terrible conflicts", including ethnic cleansing?

elements.title: Annet Genestier (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the bird subspecies Alcippe dubia genestieri is named after Annet Genestier, a French missionary-botanist in China who also built Zhongding Catholic Church in 1908?

elements.title: My Tender Matador (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the historical-romance novel My Tender Matador includes a fictionalized version of the attempted assassination of Augusto Pinochet?

elements.title: Zack Johnson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in college, American football lineman Zack Johnson played directly next to Zack Johnson?
